awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research:  Transnational Family Movements
awd_abstract_narration:
Security concerns increasingly shape local as well as transnational debates. The research supported by this award examines how these debates affect understandings of the role of the family. Family cultures are usually understood to be rooted in particular practices and places, but efforts to securitize the family in crisis contexts may take on common characteristics. Therefore, to understand what is happening in the United States, a comparative perspective is required. This project leverages ethnography's unique capacity for combining deep listening with social analysis to better understand the conceptualizations and concerns that motivate family-focused security movements.

The research will take place primarily in Mexico, with shorter trips to other sites where security crises and significant family movements have emerged in recent years. The researcher will collect data through archival research to trace the history of these movements; textual analyses of media accounts; participant observation at multiple sites and across organizational scales; interviews; social network analysis; and GIS and timeline mapping of the global circulation of ideas about the family. These data will be analyzed to understand the historical, cultural, and geopolitical significance of individual family movement cases and how they connect to larger transnational developments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research project ethnographically examines the relationship between illiberal politics, (in)security, and gender and sexual politics through ethnograhic analysis of the knowledge politics and organizing practices of anti-gender movements in Mexico. The project aims to understand how and why anti-gender organizing has become an ubiquitous mobilizing strategy and feature of illiberal populist trends in Latin America and around the world by examining the interrelated roles played by security crises, economic precarity, political polarization, rapid social change, and deepening interpersonal and institutuional distrust, all of which have widely impacted Mexico in recent years.

The research contributes to anthropological and social scientific theorizations of rising illiberal politics around the world and how popular support for these political trends is cultivated. The research found that three registers of (in)securities characterize the sentiments and rhetoric of anti-gender movement supporters and can act as drivers of popular support for illiberal political views. These overlapping (in)securities --epistemic, ontological, and existential-- often find their expression in anti-gender conspiracy theories that narrate grievances about asymmetrical geopolitical and economic power, air the social strain and status anxiety amidst a rapid reorganization of social roles and identities, and vent anger and disillusionment over the failures of democracy.

The research traced the transnational reach and scope of anti-gender conspiracy theories and movements through a social network analysis of anti-gender movements transnationally to better understand the relationship between national and transnational social movements. Social network data mapping the infrastructure of anti-gender movements in and beyond Mexico generated through the research informs our understanding of how conspiracy theories circulate transnationally and can inform efforts to address the rise of misinformation about marginalized groups.
